Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation2: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Story:
I watched my stepbrother, Max, tighten his helmet, his skateboard already perched at the top of the old, cracked ramp behind our house. He grinned at me, eyes shining with excitement, and I felt a knot form in my stomach. As his step-sibling, I knew I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t do anything too reckless. But he was determined to try this new trick, and I could see he wouldn’t listen to warnings easily.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the code sample my mentor assigned was still unfinished. I had barely started, and the deadline was creeping closer. My mentor expected me to be responsible, to show progress and commitment. I could almost hear her voice in my head, urging me to focus and not let distractions get in the way.

Max called out, asking if I’d watch him, maybe even film the attempt. I hesitated, torn between staying to keep him safe and rushing inside to work on my assignment. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I stood frozen, heart pounding, unsure which role I was supposed to choose.
